docs.lead_paragraph: MIDDLE EAST IRAN: LIBERAL TELLS OF ELECTION BAN The head of the liberal Islamic opposition said all its candidates in the provinces had been barred from running in February's key parliamentary elections. ''It's the first stage in a long battle,'' Ibrahim Yazdi, secretary general of the Iran Freedom Movement, said after newspapers reported that 401 candidates of the 6,860 who applied to run had been rejected by the interior ministry. Mr. Yazdi said he had heard no word about the barring of Freedom Movement candidates in Tehran, where 30 seats are being contested. (Agence France-Presse) IRAQ: NEW FERRY LINK A second ferry line linking Iraq to other nations in the Persian Gulf has opened with the arrival of a car ferry at the Iraqi port of Um Qasr from Bahrain. Iraq, barred from international air traffic under United Nations sanctions, was permitted to open the first ferry link in the gulf last year, from Dubai. The ferries take passengers, cars and some cargo, since each passenger is allowed about 220 pounds of baggage. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: So, did it work? Whatever else can be said about Wisconsin's crusade to end welfare -- whether one judges it kind or cruel, whether one thinks it left the safety net stronger or in shreds -- the effort achieved two things.

headline.main: Bold Effort Leaves Much Unchanged for the Poor

docs.abstract: Last article of series, Life After Welfare, finds that Wisconsin's crusade to end welfare has left far fewer people on welfare and put more people to work, but that it has made little difference in lives of poor, socially or economically; former welfare recipients, employed in entry-level jobs, cannot afford to move from violent neighborhoods; there continue to be absent fathers, bare cupboards, epidemics of depression and temptations of drugs; street life tempts children whether parents work or not; new workers often resist workplace rules and boss's authority, prompting much job-hopping; working mothers have less time for their children; prospects of poor children may depend more profoundly on whether they have support of their fathers than whether their mothers move from subsistence welfare checks into subsistence jobs; photos (L)
docs.snippet: So, did it work?    Whatever else can be said about Wisconsin's crusade to end welfare -- whether one judges it kind or cruel, whether one thinks it left the safety net stronger or in shreds -- the effort achieved two things.
